dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Over 600 companies have now joined the advertising boycott of Twitter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Over six hundred companies have now joined the advertising boycott of Twitter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With over 500 companies having now joined the advertising boycott of Facebook called for by top civil rights groups, some investors are concerned about the companys lost revenuebut most Wall Street firms estimate that Facebook is still looking at less than a 5% hit to overall revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge number, and it's being led by those civil rights groups with the #StopHateforProfits campaign.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge number, and it's being led by those civil rights groups with the #StopHateforProfits campaign.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook shares initially plunged by 8% last Friday amid an increasing number of big brandsmost recently joined by Pfizer, Lego and Dunkin Donutsannouncing that they will stop working with the tech giant as part of the #StopHateforProfits campaign, which has now grown to include more than 500 advertisers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But uh, Wall Street analysts like Rohit Kulkarni from MKM Partners are saying the revenue hit might be less than 10% overall.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But uh, Wall Street analysts like Rohit Kulkarni from M K M Partners are saying the revenue hit might be less than ten percent overall.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook is looking at a less than 5% hit to its overall revenue, said Rohit Kulkarni, an analyst for MKM Partners, in a recent note.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Morgan Stanley's Brian Nowak estimates losing the top 50 advertisers would only be around a $2 billion hit per month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Morgan Stanley's Brian Nowak estimates losing the top fifty advertisers would only be around a two dollars billion hit per month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a scenario where the company loses business from its top 100 advertisers, that would only be around a $1 billion hit to revenue per month, Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak estimates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, in the grand scheme of things for a company that size... it's significant but maybe not catastrophic?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, in the grand scheme of things for a company that size... it's significant but maybe not catastrophic?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And if the boycott only lasts three months, Citi analysts think the stock impact is just $3 per share.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And if the boycott only lasts three months, Citi analysts think the stock impact is just three dollars per share.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the ad boycott only lasts one month, according to Citi analysts, the likely impact on Facebooks stock is just $1 per share, and if Facebook is unable to convince the companies who are boycotting to resume business, the impact on its stock would be $17 per share, they estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though they did say if those advertisers don't come back, it could be more like $27 per share.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though they did say if those advertisers don't come back, it could be more like twenty seven dollars per share.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: if Facebook is unable to convince the companies who are boycotting to resume business, the impact on its stock would be $17 per share, they estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But Twitter has millions of paying advertisers—Procter & Gamble, for example, is huge globally but only makes up about 0.75% of Twitter's revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Twitter has millions of paying advertisers-Procter and Gamble, for example, is huge globally but only makes up about zero point seven five percent of Twitter's revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Procter & Gamble, for example, is the largest advertiser in the world but is estimated to account for less than 0.50% of Facebooks revenues, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the revenue base is actually pretty diversified, which helps cushion the blow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the revenue base is actually pretty diversified, which helps cushion the blow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Advertisers were already winding down spending amid the coronavirus pandemic, Kulkarni notes, but Facebook has a diverse revenue base, with millions of paying advertisers; Procter & Gamble, for example, is the largest advertiser in the world but is estimated to account for less than 0.50% of Facebooks revenues, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And advertisers were already increasing spending during the pandemic, so timing might soften this too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And advertisers were already increasing spending during the pandemic, so timing might soften this too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Advertisers were already winding down spending amid the coronavirus pandemic, Kulkarni notes, but Facebook has a diverse revenue base, with millions of paying advertisers; Procter & Gamble, for example, is the largest advertiser in the world but is estimated to account for less than 0.50% of Facebooks revenues, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, seeing names like McDonald's, Hasbro, Starbucks pull out—it's a big signal, even if the financial hit isn't massive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, seeing names like McDonald's, Hasbro, Starbucks pull out-it's a big signal, even if the financial hit isn't massive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It's more about reputation and public pressure than pure dollars at this point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It's more about reputation and public pressure than pure dollars at this point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And investors seem to agree—the stock actually went up 8% last Friday amid all this news.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And investors seem to agree-the stock actually went up eight percent last Friday amid all this news.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook shares initially plunged by 8% last Friday amid an increasing number of big brandsmost recently joined by Pfizer, Lego and Dunkin Donutsannouncing that they will stop working with the tech giant as part of the #StopHateforProfits campaign, which has now grown to include more than 500 advertisers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kind of counterintuitive, but I guess the market's it as manageable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kind of counterintuitive, but I guess the market's it as manageable.

artist_script:
HostA: Over 600 companies have now joined the advertising boycott of Twitter.
HostB: Yeah, that's a huge number, and it's being led by those civil rights groups with the #StopHateforProfits campaign.
HostA: But uh, Wall Street analysts like Rohit Kulkarni from MKM Partners are saying the revenue hit might be less than 10% overall.
HostB: Right, and Morgan Stanley’s Brian Nowak estimates losing the top 50 advertisers would only be around a $2 billion hit per month.
HostA: Which, you know, in the grand scheme of things for a company that size... it’s significant but maybe not catastrophic?
HostB: Exactly. And if the boycott only lasts three months, Citi analysts think the stock impact is just $3 per share.
HostA: Though they did say if those advertisers don't come back, it could be more like $27 per share.
HostB: But Twitter has millions of paying advertisers—Procter & Gamble, for example, is huge globally but only makes up about 0.75% of Twitter’s revenue.
HostA: So the revenue base is actually pretty diversified, which helps cushion the blow.
HostB: And advertisers were already increasing spending during the pandemic, so timing might soften this too.
HostA: Still, seeing names like McDonald’s, Hasbro, Starbucks pull out—it’s a big signal, even if the financial hit isn’t massive.
HostB: For sure. It’s more about reputation and public pressure than pure dollars at this point.
HostA: And investors seem to agree—the stock actually went up 8% last Friday amid all this news.
HostB: Which is kind of counterintuitive, but I guess the market’s it as manageable.
